title: 107_s995
content: PROTECTION OF CERTAIN DISCLOSURES OF INFORMATION BY FEDERAL EMPLOYEES. Amendment to Section 2302(b)(8) of title 5, United States Code clarifies disclosures made by federal employees without restrictions on time, place, form, motive, context, or prior disclosure. It includes disclosures made in the ordinary course of duties that are believed to be credible evidence of any violation. The amendment to Section 2302(b)(8) of title 5, United States Code allows federal employees to make disclosures without restrictions on time, place, form, motive, context, or prior disclosure. This includes disclosures made in the ordinary course of duties that are believed to be credible evidence of any violation. Federal employees or applicants can make disclosures of credible evidence of violations of laws, mismanagement, waste of funds, abuse of authority, danger to public health or safety, or false statements to Congress. Federal employees or applicants can disclose information to members of Congress or authorized individuals with appropriate security clearance. The amendment to Section 2302(b) of title 5, United States Code, defines "disclosure" as a formal or informal communication. Additionally, Section 2302(a)(2)(A) is amended to include the implementation or enforcement of any nondisclosure policies, forms, and agreements. The amendment to Section 2302(b) of title 5, United States Code prohibits the implementation or enforcement of any nondisclosure policy, form, or agreement that does not contain specific statements. The curr_chunk discusses employee obligations, rights, or liabilities created by various laws and statutes related to disclosures, including those governing disclosures to Congress, disclosures of illegality, waste, fraud, abuse, public health or safety threats, and disclosures that could compromise national security. The curr_chunk discusses the incorporation of definitions, requirements, obligations, rights, sanctions, and liabilities from Executive orders and statutory provisions into agreements. It also mentions the authority of Special Counsel in civil actions. The Special Counsel has the authority to obtain judicial review of any final order or decision of the Board in civil actions related to specific sections of the law. The Special Counsel can seek judicial review of a Board decision by first petitioning for reconsideration, and if denied, can then petition the Court of Appeals. All parties involved in the Board proceedings have the right to appear in the Court of Appeals. The Court of Appeals has discretion in granting the petition for judicial review. The Special Counsel can seek judicial review by petitioning any appellate court of competent jurisdiction as provided under subsection (b)(2). The court of appeals has discretion in granting the petition for judicial review.
